did.head: Papers Summary
did.abstract: The Henry C. Smith papers consist of letters and a few photographs recounting Smith’s daily experiences in the United States Army in flight cadet training school in Ithaca, New York; Dallas, Texas; and Waco, Texas during World War I.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Henry C. Smith was born in 1896 March. In 1918, he enlisted in the United States Army, intending to train as a pilot. He first entered cadet training school in 1918 April at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York. In July, he was transferred to continue his ground training at Camp Dick near Dallas, Texas. In September, he was assigned to Rich Field in Waco, Texas where he continued flight training until the war ended. After being discharged circa 1918 December, Smith return home to Pennsylvania where he remained for several years. By 1930, he was married to Ann Smith and had moved from Wilkinsburg, Pennsylvania, to East Washington, Pennsylvania. By 1940, he had moved to Ohio. The date and location of his death are unknown.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Henry C. Smith papers consist of materials from 1918, with some undated items. The papers are correspondence from Smith to his mother in Pennsylvania, Sarah Jane Miller Smith, recounting his experiences training to be a pilot in the United States Army during World War I.
Series I, Correspondence, consists of outgoing correspondence from Smith along with a few photographs, a postcard, and a printed copy of a poem.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection arrived in a cardboard box. The letters were organized chronologically although some letters were out of sequence. The folder titles identified the month of the letters they contained as well as listing the number of letters and pages. Some letters were bookmarked by strips of yellow paper with short notes or symbols written in red ink.

The collection largely retains its original order. Letters that were out of sequence were moved to their correct chronological position. Folder titles were simplified to just the name of the month, omitting the unlabeled numbers identifying how many letters and pages each folder contained. Envelopes were copied before being deaccessioned.
